fr:title.text: Additive functor is faithful iff it reflects exactness ›

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Additive functor is faithful iff it reflects exactness ›

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We first prove the forward implication. Given a sequence X \xrightarrow {f} Y \xrightarrow {g} Z whose image under F is exact, by faithfulness F(g \mathbin {\circ } f) = 0 implies g \mathbin {\circ } f = 0. Now we wish to prove the composite \ker g \to Y \to \operatorname {coker} f is zero. We can decompose its image under F as F(\ker g) \to \ker Fg \to FY \to \operatorname {coker} Ff \to F(\operatorname {coker} f). But the inner two morphisms compose to zero, so by faithfulness we get our result.

On the other hand, suppose F reflects exactness. Given a morphism f : X \to Y, suppose Ff = 0, then FX \xrightarrow {\textrm {id}} FX \xrightarrow {Ff} FY is exact. Hence X \xrightarrow {\textrm {id}} X \xrightarrow {f} Y is also exact, so f = 0 too.

fr:title.text: Additive functor is faithful iff it reflects exactness

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Additive functor is faithful iff it reflects exactness

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: An additive functor is faithful iff it reflects exactness.

This implies that faithful additive functors reflects kernels, cokernels, etc. Note that faithful functors need not preserve kernels or cokernels. This is because we can take the direct sum of a faithful functor with an arbitrary additive functor and the result is still faithful. The second summand can behave badly.

We first prove the forward implication. Given a sequence X \xrightarrow {f} Y \xrightarrow {g} Z whose image under F is exact, by faithfulness F(g \mathbin {\circ } f) = 0 implies g \mathbin {\circ } f = 0. Now we wish to prove the composite \ker g \to Y \to \operatorname {coker} f is zero. We can decompose its image under F as F(\ker g) \to \ker Fg \to FY \to \operatorname {coker} Ff \to F(\operatorname {coker} f). But the inner two morphisms compose to zero, so by faithfulness we get our result.

On the other hand, suppose F reflects exactness. Given a morphism f : X \to Y, suppose Ff = 0, then FX \xrightarrow {\textrm {id}} FX \xrightarrow {Ff} FY is exact. Hence X \xrightarrow {\textrm {id}} X \xrightarrow {f} Y is also exact, so f = 0 too.
